measured_by: General Knowledge Task with Confidence Level
justification: The paper describes using a general knowledge task where participants answer questions and rate their confidence level, specifically mentioning studies that have found underconfidence in depressed individuals compared to controls (Stone et al., Soderstrom et al., Fu et al.).

measured_by: Memory Task with Judgments of Learning (JOL) and Feeling of Knowing (FOK)
justification: Various studies discussed in the paper used memory tasks that involved participants rating their confidence using JOL (prediction of recall) or FOK (confidence in later retrieval), specifically noting differences between OCD patients and controls (Tolin et al., Le Berre et al.).

In clinical schizophrenia, the paper discusses studies that used perceptual decision-making tasks to measure confidence discrimination and metacognitive sensitivity using meta-d', indicating overconfidence in errors as a specific impairment (Davies et al., Moritz et al.).

measured_by: Source-Monitoring Task with Confidence Level, Confidence in Errors, and Discrimination
justification: The review highlights the use of source-monitoring tasks in assessing metamemory abilities. It specifically mentions research on schizophrenia where participants evaluated their memory confidence and showed overconfidence in errors (Moritz et al., Kircher et al.).

measured_by: General Knowledge Task with Confidence Level
justification: The author discusses using a general knowledge task to evaluate participants' confidence level, highlighting studies where pathological gamblers showed overconfidence as compared to non-problem gamblers (Goodie et al., Lakey et al.).

measured_by: Prospective Memory Task with Confidence Level
justification: The paper highlights studies that used a prospective memory task to assess confidence, showing that confidence judgments in clinical GD were disconnected from accuracy (Cuttler et al.).
